RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Pioneer Energy  

Vaporcatchers at the Raindance Tank Battery (Facility ID: 100000237585)



ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES



Pioneer Energy (Pioneer) owns and operates Vaporcatcher skids and a natural gas liquids (NGL) tank at the Raindance Tank Battery site in Weld County, Colorado.  The Vaporcatcher is designed to process tank vapors and recover liquid products from vapors by physical separation and cryogenic means.  The Vaporcatcher is considered a small natural gas processing plant for regulatory purposes. NGLs recovered from this process are marketed for off-site sales.



Pioneer has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the company's efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the process. Pioneer's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within their capabilities, and notify the necessary outside agencies. 



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The Vaporcatchers at the Raindance Tank Battery are located approximately 1.6 miles southwest of Windsor, Colorado. From the intersection of County Road 13 and County Road 64, drive one mile east on County Road 64 and then drive one-half mile north to reach the site. At this location, the Vaporcatcher process is used produce the following products:



1. Y grade mixture from natural gas (also known as NGLs)

2. Light Gas



The NGL product contains ethane, propane, butanes, pentanes, and heavier hydrocarbon components. The regulated flammable substances include these same components. This facility does not handle regulated toxic substances above their threshold quantities and there are no toxic release scenario

s to consider.



OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS



There is one worst-case scenario (WCS) associated with a release of flammable substances at the Vaporcatchers at the Raindance Tank Battery.  The scenario consists of a vapor cloud explosion involving 79,710 pounds of a flammable mixture contained in a full 18,000-gallon NGL Tank. The WCS results in the largest impacted area with a 0.3-mile radius.



The site is located near a residential area and future golf course. The WCS has an offsite endpoint and would affect several adjacent homes as offsite nearby public receptors.  Pioneer has controls to prevent such a release and to manage consequences. Mitigation measures include relief valves, check valves, grounding equipment, and rupture disks.



The alternative release scenario (ARS) for the flammable substances at the Vaporcatchers at the Raindance Tank Battery is assumed to be a vapor cloud explosion resulting from the release of 11,643 pounds of NGLs from a pipe between a Vaporcatcher skid and the NGL tank. The release would occur from a break in the 1-inch pipeline that would involve 202 pounds per minute being released for 60 minutes before the leak was stopped. The ARS would impact a radius of 0.2 miles, which includes an offsite endpoint and nearby public receptors. 



GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Vaporcatchers at the Raindance Tank Battery are not covered by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program since it can be operated remotely and Pioneer does not keep employees at its location. This results in the process being Program Level 2. The following sections detail how Pioneer complies with the Program 2 requirements for accident prevention. 



A. Process Safety Information/Process Controls



Pioneer keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process.  These technical documents address the following:



1. Chemical properties and associated hazards

2. Necessary Block Flo

w Diagrams of the process

3. Maximum intended inventories

4. Upper and lower limits of process equipment

5. Equipment design basis and configuration information

6. Identification of necessary regulatory equipment design documents

7. Sufficient information to assure good engineering practices



Chemical specific information, including hazard and emergency response/exposure considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDS).  For specific areas within the process, Pioneer has documented safety-related limits for specific parameters such as temperatures, level and composition in the operator's procedures manual.  The company maintains the overall process within these limits by using remote controls and monitoring instruments, trained personnel and protective instrument systems such as automated shutdown systems. 



The facility also maintains technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressures, temperature and electrical ratings.  This information, in combination with procedures and equipment operating history, provides a basis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed changes to safety features to ensure these are not compromised. 



B. Hazard Review



The Vaporcatchers at the Raindance Tank Battery identify and control hazards associated with the RMP covered scenario.  This program systematically examines and explores for potential hazards, then establishes controls to put in place to manage the potential hazards.  The hazard review is conducted using checklists by Pioneer's employees and/or consultants who have operation, maintenance, engineering, and safety experience.  This review evaluates and makes recommendations to management of the potential hazards identified.  The findings are forwarded to Pioneer for review.  The approved mitigation options in response to the hazard review findings are tracked

until they are completed.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.



Pioneer will periodically update and revalidate the hazard analysis results.  These periodic reviews will be conducted at least every five years and will be conducted at this frequency until the regulated process is no longer operating.  The results and findings from these updates will be documented and retained.



C. Operating Procedures



Pioneer maintains written Operating Procedures of the covered process that address primary operations mandated by OSHA, EPA, Good Engineering Practice and manufacturers.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  Procedures will be periodically reviewed and annually certified as current accurate by management.  The procedures are maintained current and accurate revising them as necessary by employee suggestion, compliance audit, hazard review, and Good Engineering practice.



Covered process Operating Procedures are readily available to operators for the process unit and to other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job task and ensure the covered process is operating within its safe limits.



D.  Training



The Vaporcatchers at the Raindance Tank Battery have implemented a comprehensive training program for employees involved in operating the covered process.  New employees receive basic training in process operations if they are not already familiar with such operations.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn specific duties and tasks.  A performance review and written test or hands on observation specific to the plant operations is administered and must be successfully completed during this training period.  After the operator demonstrates adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are allowed to work independently.

In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years, or more frequently upon request.  The training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify and demonstrate skills



E. Mechanical Integrity/Maintenance



The Vaporcatchers at the Raindance Tank Battery have established practices and procedures for the safe operation of fixed, rotating and emergency shutdown equipment.  The basic aspects of the program include, but are not limited to, the following:



1. Conducting training

2. Developing written procedures

3. Performing inspections and tests

4. Correcting identified deficiencies

5. Applying quality assurance measures



In combination, these activities form a system to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process.



Maintenance personnel receive training on:



1. Overview of the process

2. Safety and Health hazards

3. Applicable maintenance procedures

4. Emergency response plan

5. Applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.



Written procedures provide that work is performed in a consistent manner and serve as a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed to help verify that equipment functions as intended and that equipment is within acceptable limits.  If a deficiency is identified and the situation presents an immediate safety concern, the deficiency is corrected before placing the equipment back into service.  



An integral part of the maintenance program is quality assurance.  The Vaporcatchers at the Raindance Tank Battery incorporate quality assurance measures into equipment purchases, leases, and repairs.  This helps to determine that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made. 



F. Safe W

ork Practices



Pioneer has long-standing safe work practices as mandated by OSHA, Industrial Standards, and Good Engineering Practice in place to help provide employee, public and process safety.



G. Incident Investigation



Pioneer will promptly investigate incidents related to a covered scenario that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion, property damage, environmental loss or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective action to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent future occurrences and forwards these results to management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented and investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years. 



H. Compliance Audits



At least every three years a Compliance Audit addressing OSHA, EPA, RMP and Good Engineering Practices are conducted by employees and management of the Raindane Tank Battery.  This audit team will develop findings that are forwarded to management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are completed.  Final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.  



I. Release Containment/Controls/Mitigation



The following controls and equipment are in place to help prevent and mitigate a release.



1. Process relief valves and check valves 

2. Automated and manual shutoffs to permit isolation of the process

3. Automated process shutdown system to remotely shut down equipment to their fail-safe position

4. Curbing or diking to contain liquids releases

5. Grounding equipment

6. Rupture Disks

7. Fire suppression and extinguishing system



F

IVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The Vaporcatchers at the Raindance Tank Battery are a new facility.  There have been no accidental releases from a covered process that resulted in death, injury or significant property damage on site, or known off-site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage. 

 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



The Vaporcatchers at the Raindance Tank Battery site is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b). The company maintains written emergency procedures, which are in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment.  These procedures identify steps to be taken in case of an accidental release. However, the facility is an unmanned location and company personnel are not trained to be first responders to large fires and should a release occur from one of the vessels the facility would rely on the local fire department to respond.  



Employees receive training in the procedures to be followed when certain employees must remain to operate critical plant operations before they evacuate.  The Vaporcatchers at the Raindance Tank Battery site has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Fire Department, Police and Sheriff's Office).  This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.



RMP MANAGEMENT



Pioneer has assigned responsibility for the risk management program to the Vice President of Business Development and maintains a management system to oversee program elements.

 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 



There are currently no planned changes to improve safety. Rather, the company believes that diligent compliance with our RMP Prevention Program forms the framework that allows for the continued improvement to the level of safety at the Vaporcatchers at the Raindance Tank Battery. Some of the key components

of the program that will help maintain and, where applicable, improve safety are:



Ensuring that Pioneer considers the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures.



The hazard review provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards. 



Ensuring that equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous release thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.



Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that Pioneer maintains and increases the level of safety protection.
